description: Public transport officials have released warnings today about potential lengthy delays, with close to 200,000 fans expected to descend on ANZ Stadium over the weekend
title: Adele Sydney concert-goers warned to expect travel delays
title_page: Adele Sydney concert-goers warned to expect travel delays | Daily Mail Online
text:
Those wanting to say Hello to superstar Adele as she performs in Sydney on Friday and Saturday night should plan to leave early.
Approximately three hours early, if rumour has it!
Public transport officials have released warnings today about potential lengthy delays, with close to 200,000 fans expected to descend on ANZ Stadium over the weekend, according to News.com.au.
Rumour Has It: Those wanting to attend Adele's concerts in Sydney Friday and Saturday night have been urged to leave early and expect delays
Those thinking of driving to the venue have also been warned against the idea, with the NSW police tweeting that all the car-parks have been sold out.
'Unless you pre-booked, don't drive,' they Tweeted.
Public transport may not fare much better, with long-planned train track maintenance on the T1 Northern and North Shore line, Central Coast and Newcastle line and the Hunter line unable to be rescheduled.
It's not all bad news though, with the cost of bus and train fare included in the ticket and lasting until early the following morning.
I ain't got no time for that: NSW Police tweeted that the car parks at the Adele concerts were sold out, advising fans not to drive unless they had pre-booked
Delays: Public transport is free with your Adele ticket for the Sydney shows, with extra buses to compensate for track works
Adele is in town to perform on the third leg of her Australian tour, having already sold-outs stadium shows in Perth and Brisbane.
The songstress added a second Sydney show back in November, with the concerts expected to be the biggest events staged at the venue since the Olympics back in 2000.
Fans should be wary what they plan to bring with them though, not just because they may have to lug it with them on public transport.
According to Mamamia, there is a list of prohibited items better left home, including alcohol, knives and video or audio recording equipment.
Oversized bags, eskies and confetti are some of the stranger articles also listed, as well as fireworks.
Be prepared: There is a list of prohibited items better left home, including alcohol, knives and video or audio recording equipment
Glamourous: The mother-of-one kicked off her first Australian tour in Perth last month, gracing the stage in a stunning wine red gown, complete with long train and 10,000 Swarovski crystals
The pop diva famously scrapped the use of pyrotechnics from her tour after her son Angelo received debris in his eye during a rehearsal for the Perth performance.
The mother-of-one kicked off her first Australian tour in Perth last month, gracing the stage in a stunning wine red gown, complete with long train and 10,000 Swarovski crystals.
The Brit star belted out hits from her latest album 25, including Hello, All I Ask and Water Under the Bridge.
Adele caused controversy at her Brisbane concert when she bluntly told the Deputy Mayor to 'shut up' while addressing the crowd at her Saturday night show, after hearing he suggested the venue could not safely hold a crowd of 60,000.
